slides.heading: Change
slides.text: Chris Gardner knows where he was when his life changed. He was sitting on the floor of a public bathroom in a subway station. He was homeless and the single father of a young son. His job did not pay much. His son's mother had left them. Everything was against him. If you ask Gardner, though, he will tell you that this was the moment he started to become a success. He made a conscious choice to change.

slides.text: It worked. Today, Chris Gardner is a wealthy business owner. His story was told in a movie, The Pursuit of Happyness, starring Will Smith. When people ask Gardner for the secret to his success, he tells them, "The secret is there is no secret. It's the basics."

slides.heading: Moving Forward
slides.text:
Gardner never imagined he would end up on that bathroom floor. He had hard times growing up, but his mother had high expectations for him. She taught him to believe he could become anything he wanted to be.

For his son's sake, Gardner decided not to stay in that subway station. He looked inside himself and found the power to move forward.

But Gardner's story can be anybody's story. The key is finding out what motivates you, or gets you moving. Love for his son got Gardner moving off that subway floor and into a new life. Once he got a job as a stockbroker and worked hard to succeed in that job, he found that he loved his work, too. Love was Gardner's motivation.

slides.heading: Choosing What You Love
slides.text:
Gardner believes success is built one choice at a time. He tells people to work hard and to start with baby steps. "And more important than that, find something that you love," Gardner adds, "Do something that gets you so excited you can't wait to get out of bed in the morning."

To some people, Gardner's advice is not realistic. Can people really overcome problems by acting consciously? Maybe Gardner's story is one in a million. Not everyone will achieve the wealth that he did. But we all have the ability to be motivated.

slides.heading: Motivating Yourself
slides.text: Some people are motivated by outside forces. You might do your math homework because you are afraid of what your family will say if you get a bad grade. Other people get their motivation from within. That is called self-motivation. If you become self-motivated, you might do your math homework because you want to be a video game programmer. You act on the belief that learning math will help you reach your goal.

slides.text: Self-motivation is a mark of your individuality, or your personal likes and dislikes, talents, and interests. Self-motivated people start with what makes them who they are. They use those strengths to help them become who they want to be.

slides.heading: Get Moving
slides.text:
Give self-motivation a try. You can use these steps to study harder, learn a new skill, or make plans for the future.

 

Do what you love. Find a connection between what you can do, what you need to do, and what you want to do.

 

Set reasonable goals. Do not take on so much that you get overwhelmed, or so little that you get bored.

 

Start with baby-steps. Break big tasks into smaller parts.

slides.text:
Stay positive. Do not put blocks in your own path. If you think "I can't do this," you will keep yourself from even trying.

Give yourself permission to fail. You will not always get everything right the first time. Do not give up. Learn from your mistakes.

Ask for help, and give it to others. Family members, friends, and teachers can help you stay motivated. When you succeed, do what Chris Gardner does. Encourage others to achieve their goals.
